name: Transcranial Ultrasound (TUS)
summary: A non-invasive neuromodulation technique using focused or low-intensity ultrasound waves to modulate brain activity, currently under investigation for psychiatric and neurological disorders.
description: Transcranial Ultrasound (TUS), also called low-intensity focused ultrasound (LIFU), is an emerging brain stimulation method that uses acoustic energy to modulate neuronal excitability and network dynamics. Unlike magnetic stimulation, ultrasound can target deeper brain structures with millimeter precision. Research suggests it may influence neuroplasticity, brain oscillations, and functional connectivity. Clinical applications are still largely experimental, but early studies show promise in treating mood disorders, movement disorders, and chronic pain.

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe at low intensities; transient headache, dizziness, or scalp sensations may occur. Long-term safety is still under study.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Preliminary — early human trials and animal studies.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Ongoing clinical trials in psychiatry and neurology; strong preclinical evidence for neuromodulatory effects.

sections.text: Transcranial ultrasound uses focused acoustic energy to mechanically influence neuronal membranes, ion channels, and local microcirculation. It can either excite or inhibit brain activity depending on pulse parameters, potentially inducing long-term neuroplasticity.

sections.preparation: Experimental; patient typically seated or lying down with head stabilized.
procedure: Ultrasound transducer positioned on the scalp over target brain region.
Low-intensity ultrasound pulses delivered under controlled parameters.
Neuronavigation or MRI guidance often used to enhance precision.
sections.frequency: Not standardized; varies in research protocols.

short_term: Changes in brain activity measurable on EEG/fMRI
long_term: Potential symptom relief in depression, tremor, or epilepsy (experimental)

ideal_candidates: Patients in clinical trials for refractory depression, epilepsy, or movement disorders

facility: Specialized research centers or hospitals with ultrasound neuromodulation equipment

studies: Pilot studies in major depression suggest mood improvements with TUS.
Animal models demonstrate effects on seizure activity and neuroplasticity.
Early research suggests precision targeting of deep brain regions is feasible.
sections.limitations: Efficacy and safety not yet established in large randomized clinical trials.

sections.cost_effectiveness: Unknown until clinical efficacy is proven

sections.pregnancy: Avoid until safety data are available
sections.comorbidities: Caution with implanted devices or unstable medical conditions

items: Experimental neuromodulation technique; not yet FDA-approved.
Capable of targeting deep brain structures unlike TMS.
Parameter optimization and long-term safety remain open research questions.
